facts.text: Writ Petition No. 184 of 1961 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 184 of 1961. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR J. on January 16, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the legality

facts.text: Petition challenges legality of amendment in s. 15 of the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947 by s. 2 of the Assam Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1960 (Act XIII of 1960).

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the amendment introduced in s. 15 of the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act XVII of 1947 , by s. 2 of the Assam Sales Tax  Amendment  Act, 1960  Act XIII of 1960 ,

facts.text: Amendment deleted sub-s. (b) of item (i) of sub-cl. (b) of cl. (1) of s.15, making sales of goods to registered dealer for use in production taxable.

anchor.surface_text: by which sub-s.  b  of item  i  of sub-cl.  b  of cl.  1  was deleted and thereby sales of goods to a registered dealer intended for use in production of goods for sale became liable to sales tax.

facts.text: Petitioner is a limited company carrying on business of manufacturing, selling and supplying iron and steel materials in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company is a limited companypany carrying on in the State of Assam its business of manufacturing, selling and supplying iron and steel materials.

facts.text: Petitioner held Registration Certificate under Assam Sales Tax Act before 1960 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: It held a Registration Certificate under the Assam Sales Tax Act, as it was before the amendment of 1960. Under that Act all its purchases for use in manufacture or production of goods taxable under the Act were exempt from sales tax

facts.text: After amendment, deletion in Registration Certificate of goods like cast iron, iron plates, steel bars and galvanised wire used in manufacture.

anchor.surface_text: but after the amendment of the Act there was a deletion in the Registration Certificate of certain goods, e.g., cast iron, iron plates, steel bars and galvanised wire which were used by the petitioner in the manufacture of its finished products which were also taxable in the State.

facts.text: Petitioner became liable to pay tax on goods purchased for use in manufacture, increasing cost of production.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently it has become liable to pay tax on those goods purchased for use in the manufacture of goods and the companyt of production has thereby gone up.

facts.text: Petitioner raised point 1: amendment violative of Art. 14 as it discriminates between manufacturers supplying per orders and those manufacturing on own account.

anchor.surface_text: Three points were raised by the petitioner-  1  that the amendment introduced by Act XIII of 1960 is violative of Art. 14 because it discriminates between manufacturers who supply goods according to orders received and others who manufacture goods on their own account and sell them

facts.text: Petitioner raised point 2: restriction by Amending Act excessive and violative of Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the restriction imposed by the Amending Act is excessive and violative of Art. 19  1  f  and

facts.text: Petitioner raised point 3: refusal to amend Registration Certificate affects rights under Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the refusal to amend the Registration Certificate by number reinstating the articles mentioned above affects the rights of the petitioner Company under Art. 19 1   f .

facts.text: Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Act XVII of 1947) defines 'contract' in s.2(2)(a)(b).

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of deciding these questions it is necessary to refer to the scheme of the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act XVII of 1947 . By s. 2 2  a  b  of that Act Contract is defined as In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or companytext,-  2  companytract means any agreement for carrying out for cash or deferred payment or other valuable companysideration,-  a  the preparation, companytruction, fittingout, improvement or repair of any moveable property or of any building, road, bridge or other immoveable property, or  b  the installation or repair of any machinery affixed to a building or other immoveable property.

facts.text: Section 9 provides for compulsory registration; s.12 for certificate specifying classes of goods.

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of that Act provides for companypulsory registration. Section 12 provides that a dealer registered under s. 9 shall be granted a certificate of registration which shall specify the class or classes of goods in which the said dealer carries on business and such other particulars as may be prescribed.

facts.text: S.15(1)(b)(i)(b) exempted sales to registered dealer for use in manufacture/production of taxable goods; deleted by amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 1  b  i  b  and  c  deals with exemptions. It reads- 15 The net turnover shall be determined by deducting from dealers gross turnover during any given period-  1  his turnover during that period on.  a   b  sale to a registered dealer of- goods specified in the purchasing dealers certificate of registration as being intended by him for-  a   b  use in manufacture or production of any goods, the sale of which is taxable under this Act,  c  use in the execution of any companytract.

facts.text: Court holds amendment does not violate Art.14; no discrimination between contract supplies and own sales.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument is without force. The Legislature, having chosen the articles on which it thinks necessary to impose a tax, has decided to impose the tax and it is difficult to see how it can be said that the goods supplied against a companytract and goods manufactured and sold by the petitioner are similarly situated.

facts.text: Court holds no unreasonable restriction under Art.19(1)(g); matter of legislative policy.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been shown how the imposition of this tax is an unreasonable restriction on the rights of the petitioner to carry on trade, but it was submitted that by this means the petitioner will number be able to companypete with the manufacturers outside the State of Assam.

facts.text: Court holds refusal to amend certificate has no force in view of decisions on first two points.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our decision on these two points the third point, that is, the refusal of the Sales Tax Officer to amend the registration certificate will have numberforce.
In the result this petition fails and is dismissed and the rule is discharged.

arguments.claim: the amendment introduced by Act XIII of 1960 is violative of Art. 14 because it discriminates between manufacturers who supply goods according to orders received and others who manufacture goods on their own account and sell them

anchor.surface_text: Three points were raised by the petitioner-  1  that the amendment introduced by Act XIII of 1960 is violative of Art. 14 because it discriminates between manufacturers who supply goods according to orders received and others who manufacture goods on their own account and sell them

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n materials which were to be used for manufacture of goods and to be sold on their own account by the petitioner Company and materials which were purc

arguments.court_reasoning: Goods supplied against contract and goods manufactured and sold by petitioner are not similarly situated; provision against discrimination applies to persons, not articles

arguments.claim: by the omission of sub-cl. (b) discrimination was intended as between materials used for manufacture of goods sold on own account and materials purchased for use in execution of contract

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised was that by the omission of sub-cl.  b  discrimination was intended as between materials which were to be used for manufacture of goods and to be sold on their own account by the petitioner Company and materials which were purchased for use in the execution of any contract,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n materials which were to be used for manufacture of goods and to be sold on their own account by the petitioner Company and materials which were purc

arguments.court_reasoning: Not similarly situated; discrimination provision not on articles but persons

arguments.claim: object of amendment was to prevent evasion by manufacturing and sending goods out of State, could have been achieved by taxing only those materials

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that the object of the amendment of the Sales Tax Act was to prevent evasion of Sales Tax by manufacturing goods and sending them out of the State and therefore that object could have been achieved by taxing only those material which were so intended.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r classes of goods in which the said dealer carries on business and such other particulars as may be prescribed. Section 15 1  b  i  b  and  c  deals

arguments.court_reasoning: Amending Act part of general sales tax law to raise revenue; legislature decides what articles to tax

arguments.claim: Legislature decides what articles to tax and not tax to effectuate policy without introducing discrimination

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act is really a part of the General Sales Tax Act of the State of Assam the object of which is to raise revenue in the State. It is for the Legislature to decide as to what articles it should tax and what articles it should not tax and if it decided to tax certain articles in order to effectuate its policy it is difficult to see how that would introduce discrimination.

arguments.claim: goods supplied against a contract and goods manufactured and sold by the petitioner are not similarly situated

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument is without force. The Legislature, having chosen the articles on which it thinks necessary to impose a tax, has decided to impose the tax and it is difficult to see how it can be said that the goods supplied against a contract and goods manufactured and sold by the petitioner are similarly situated.

arguments.claim: provision against discrimination is not on articles but on persons

anchor.surface_text: Besides the provision against discrimination is not on articles but on persons.

arguments.court_reasoning: Even assuming so, goods put to different uses; legislature policy on taxing classes, courts cannot enter

arguments.claim: imposition of this tax is not an unreasonable restriction on the rights of the petitioner to carry on trade

anchor.surface_text: It has not been shown how the imposition of this tax is an unreasonable restriction on the rights of the petitioner to carry on trade, but it was submitted that by this means the petitioner will not be able to compete with the manufacturers outside the State of Assam.

arguments.claim: goods purchased are put to different uses and legislature decision to tax certain classes is policy into which courts cannot enter

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that this is so, it is clear that goods which are purchased are put to different uses and if the legislature thinks that certain classes of goods should pay the tax and not others that is a question of policy into which the courts cannot enter. We can only say that in such circumstances, per se there is no discrimination.

arguments.court_reasoning: No force in view of decisions on first two points

arguments.claim: refusal of the Sales Tax Officer to amend the registration certificate has no force

anchor.surface_text: In view of our decision on these two points the third point, that is, the refusal of the Sales Tax Officer to amend the registration certificate will have no force.

holdings.text: In our opinion this argument is without force. The Legislature, having chosen the articles on which it thinks necessary to impose a tax, has decided to impose the tax and it is difficult to see how it can be said that the goods supplied against a contract and goods manufactured and sold by the petitioner are similarly situated. Besides the provision against discrimination is not on articles but on persons.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument is without force. The Legislature, having chosen the articles on which it thinks necessary to impose a tax, has decided to impose the tax and it is difficult to see how it can be said that the goods supplied against a contract and goods manufactured and sold by the petitioner are similarly situated. Besides the provision against discrimination is

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods supplied under contract and goods manufactured for own sale not similarly situated; Art.14 discrimination applies to persons not articles; legislature entitled to choose articles for taxation.

holdings.text: It has not been shown how the imposition of this tax is an unreasonable restriction on the rights of the petitioner to carry on trade... Assuming that this is so, it is clear that goods which are purchased are put to different uses and if the legislature thinks that certain classes of goods should pay the tax and not others that is a question of policy into which the courts cannot enter. We can only say that in such circumstances, per se there is no discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: It has not been shown how the imposition of this tax is an unreasonable restriction on the rights of the petitioner to carry on trade, but it was submitted that by this means the petitioner will not be able to compete with the manufacturers outside the State of Assam. Assuming that this is so, it is clear that goods which are purchased are put to different uses and if the legislature thinks that certain classes of goods should pay the tax and

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of unreasonable restriction under Art.19(1)(f); legislative policy on taxation of goods classes not justiciable; different uses of goods justify classification; per se no discrimination.

holdings.text: There is no force in the second contention either.

anchor.surface_text: There is noforce in the second contention either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects second point on excessive restriction under Art.19(1)(f).

holdings.text: In view of our decision on these two points the third point, that is, the refusal of the Sales Tax Officer to amend the registration certificate will have no force.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our decision on these two points the third point, that is, the refusal of the Sales Tax Officer to amend the registration certificate will have noforce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Third claim under Art.19(1)(f) moot given rejection of first two points.

holdings.text: In the result this petition fails and is dismissed and the rule is discharged.
